questions.question_text: Which ADVPN configuration must be configured using a script on FortiManager, when using VPN Manager to manage FortiGate VPN tunnels?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Enabling ADVPN in the IPsec phase 1 settings is a mandatory step when configuring ADVPN, but it must be done using a script when using FortiManager's VPN Manager. This is because the toggle for ADVPN is not directly available in the IPsec phase 1 GUI within VPN Manager.
Can someone share the link to study guide?

Selected Answer: B
Study guide page 470

Selected Answer: B
B - Study guide page 470

Selected Answer: B
Based StudyGuide page 470 - B

B is correct.

Selected Answer: B

A - must be done (not with scripts)
B - must be done using scripts
C - must be done (not with scripts)
D - must be done (not with scripts)

5configure ip addresse on the ipse virtual interfaces

questions.question_text: Which action will FortiGate take when using the default settings for SSL certificate inspection, where the server name indication (SNI) does not match either the common name (CN) or any of the subject altemative names (SAN) in the server certificate?

discussion.content:
Answer: A
#Config firewall ssl-ssh-profile
 edit <profile_name>
 config https
 set sni-server-cert-check [enable* | strict | disable]

Enable: If the SNI does NOT match the CN or SAN fields in the returned server's certificate, FG uses the CN field instead of the SNI to obtain the FQDN.
Strict: If the SNI does NOT match the CN or SAN fields in the returned server's certificate, FG closes the connection.
Disable: FG does not check the SNI.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct!

Selected Answer: A
Enterprise FW study guide page 353

Selected Answer: A
By default, mode enable, will use the CN value

Selected Answer: A
Answer

Selected Answer: A
A seems to be the good one

Selected Answer: A
By default, mode enable, it will use the CN value
in Strict mode, it will close the connection.

choices.D: FortiGate closes the connection because this represents an invalid SSL/TLS configuration.
choices.A: FortiGate uses the CN information from the Subject field in the server certificate.
choices.C: FortiGate uses the SNI from the user's web browser.
choices.B: FortiGate uses the first entry listed in the SAN field in the server certificate.

choices.D: The BGP session with peer 10.127.0.75 is up.
choices.A: The router 100.64.3.1 needs to update the local AS number in its BGP configuration in order to bring up the BGP session with the local router.
choices.C: All of the neighbors displayed are part of a single BGP configuration on the local router with the neighbor-range set to a value of 4.
choices.B: The State/PfxRcd for neighbor 100.64.3.1 will not change until an administrator on the local router adjusts the inbound route filtering so that prefixes received can be added to the RIB.

comments.content:
Based on the above you posted.. 
Policy Package, ADOM database: D
Remote FortiGate directly (through CLI): "no option is provided to verify and check the configuration changes through FortiManager prior to executing it" - C
So answer is C and D

Cannot be B : Script is running on Device Database. According to Study guide page 254 and your explanation, once script is successfully run on Device DB, you must install your through install wizard to apply them on managed devices.
So, C and D are correct ! Not B

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
CLI scripts can be run in three different ways:
Device Database: By default, a script is executed on the device database. It is recommend you run the changes on the device database (default setting), as this allows you to check what configuration changes you will send to the managed device. Once scripts are run on the device database, you can install these changes to a managed device using the installation wizard.

Policy Package, ADOM database: If a script contains changes related to ADOM level objects and policies, you can change the default selection to run on Policy Package, ADOM database and can then be installed using the installation wizard.

Remote FortiGate directly (through CLI): A script can be executed directly on the device and you don’t need to install these changes using the installation wizard. As the changes are directly installed on the managed device, no option is provided to verify and check the configuration changes through FortiManager prior to executing it.

Selected Answer: CD
c and D are right

questions.question_text: How are bulk configuration changes made using FortiManager CLI scripts? (Choose two.)

choices.A: When run on the All FortiGate in ADOM, changes are automatically installed without the creation of a new revision history.
choices.C: When run on the Remote FortiGate directly, administrators do not have the option to review the changes prior to installation.
choices.D: When run on the Policy Package, ADOM database, you must use the installation wizard to apply the changes to the managed FortiGate device.
choices.B: When run on the Device Database, changes are applied directly to the managed FortiGate device.
